titleStmt.title: The Scotch wooing: or, Jockey of the Lough, and Jenny of the Lee: Jockey wooes Jenny, for to be his dear, but Jenny long time is in mickle fear; least Jockey should be false or prove unkind, but Jockey put that quite out of her mind, so that at length they fairly did agree, to strike a bargain up, as you shall see. To the tune of, Jockey's gone to the wood.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for P. Brooksby at the Golden-ball, in West-smithfield,

notesStmt.note: Place and date of publication suggested by Wing.
Verse: "Dear Jockey's gone to the wood ..."
Variant exists with different punctuation, and "near the hospital-gate," added to imprint after "at the golden-ball,".
Reproduction of original in the Harvard University, Houghton Library and the British Library.
